pros: Decent benefits, free drinks, discount
cons:
Management across most stores is committed to maintaining a toxic workplace and I have not met a single former employee who has good things to say about their time there. 

It doesn't matter how horribly customers treat you, management will either tell you to get over it or actively reward customers for abusive behaviour. When I worked there, my coworkers and I were constantly subjected to verbal (and sometimes physical) abuse and sexual harassment from customers, often the same people repeatedly. Management either minimized our concerns or gave the customer a gift card to "thank them" for purchasing at our store, while asking them not to do it again. Unsurprisingly, this tended to make things worse.

Employees were told they had to come in regardless of how sick they were. I watched my coworker almost pass out during a shift because she was so sick with the flu. Management told her she wasn't allowed to call in sick. At the very least, this is questionable behaviour where health and safety is concerned. For my part, I am disabled and when I had to give up a shift due to a flare-up, my manager mocked me and then said I wasn't "taking the responsibility seriously." 

I was also asked by my manager multiple times if I could skip school to stay longer because they "really needed extra staff right now."

Overall, the company promotes a toxic and unethical work environment. I worked at multiple locations and the same issues persisted across each store. Every other person I've spoken to who worked there says the same thing.

pros: Good benefits, well fed on breaks, rotating positions to avoid boredom.
cons:
Some positions in roatatikns are genuinely difficult labor. Moving moderatley sized refrigerators into small walkways in order to scrub disgusting floors. Often this involves getting in the way of others trying to make drinks or maneuver for some other position. Depending on how busy things are, this creates a mild to severe safety hazard. Same with floor mats- they are heavy and disgusting- moving them leaves a risky and unavoidable space for other workers, and scrubbing the grease off of them is quite difficult (especially for average to smaller individuals). 
The lack of tips can become quite demoralizing. While nearly all other coffee shops have some form of tip prompt built into their system, Starbucks I seems to be intentionally working around tips- making it impossible to tip with cards and nearly impossible on the app. Perhaps this is compensated for in the other areas of benefit in the job, but on the surface, this can contribute to a lack of feeling valued.

pros:
One of the best healthcare plans I have ever seen (ESPECIALLY for any transfolk looking for help with covering transitioning. Constantly pushing to create a kind, welcoming, inclusive, and sympathetic environment. I say this from my experiences with multiple store managers, assistant store managers, and shift supervisors.
Comfortable work! I have had quite a few jobs and this is the easiest and comfiest it has ever been so long as you and the rest of your team stay on top of your stuff
Very easy to change locations if you want to work at another store permanently or even just for a day
For the same reason as above it is usually very easy to pick up hours and shifts from other stores if you need it, you typically just call the store and ask if anybody needs their shift covered and then come in for them and let the supervisor working know whats going on
cons: We typically all have to pick up shifts and hours from other stores because in my experience Starbucks as a company would rather understaff than risk overstaffing, and so most of the baristas I'm familiar with are not happy with the amount of hours they have at their own store and have to search elsewhere. Unless you've got a small store in a small town! Then your store might have a small team in general and you will get scheduled more often because of it

pros:
•	exceptional guest experience, connecting with guests to deliver quality handcrafted beverages and food during all hours of operations, prioritizing the guest’s needs over tasks.
•	Engage with guests to meet and exceed their expectations based on Starbucks standard
cons: Speaking as a former partner, I can say with relative certainty that somewhere along the way this company has forgotten its mission: to impact the lives of customers. At the behest and guidance of friends and family, I signed on with the company to expand my horizons and attempt to make an impact in my local community, one coffee cup at a time. Initially, my store seemed like a lovely place to work; great location, wonderful coworkers, and flexible schedules. However, during my last six-nine months of employment, it became very apparent that our concern was focused less on customer satisfaction and more on the bottom line. On countless occasions, I witness my store manager disrespect fellow staff as well as guests, and when addressing the behavior it was shrugged off. Additionally, there was a lot of childish behavior being exhibited during store hours such aa; crude comments and passive-aggressiveness. On many occasions, staff would talk behind other partners' backs rather than address the problem directly with a shift or supervisor. I believe this isn't just a one-store issue, but something that is more widespread than it would appear. If Starbucks truly stands for inclusion it must take a hard look in the mirror and address some fundamental hiring and operational practices. Now, this is only one former partner's opinion but I sincerely doubt I'm alone in my thinking.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great benefits, like healthcare and Spotify, and free coffee. I think it's an especially great job for people pursuing Bachelor's Degrees with ASU. I wish they had a Masters's program. The partners are what make it worth it. I've made so many friends at the six different stores I've worked at. I honestly really loved my time as a barista and supervisor.
cons:
Not a good work/life balance. As an ASM you're expected to come in at any hour or transfer to a different store, wherever is needed, whether you want to or not. Because you belong to "the district", not the store. 
Also, if you disagree with a direction Starbucks is going or a decision your district is making, you do not have much room to fight for it. They'll tell you that "maybe the role isn't right for you", if you don't agree with them. It felt almost gaslighty how they talk you out of having any dissenting opinions, but then make the culture seem like they totally listen to you. They don't.
Also it's tough being an introvert there because you already are managing a team but then they always expect extra participation in the district. Which is understandable, but there's a lot of unexpected socialization that's tough.

review_title: Good coworkers. Not so good management and culture.
pros: I worked at Starbucks for three years before I moved on to another job. The partners at my store were, by and large, extremely friendly, supportive, good people. Schedule flexibility was good. Also, say what you will, but free coffee while at work is a solid perk.
cons:
Unfortunately, the advancement structure at Starbucks (at least at that time) rewarded/incentivized backstabbing, two-faced-ness, and rear kissing. As a result, the people in charge were usually embroiled in some kind of Game of Thrones-esque cloak and dagger drama. I can't tell you how many times I heard supervisors, ASMs, and managers covertly bad-mouthing their peers and workers to burnish their reputations and smear those they felt might be in the way of further promotion. Many times I witnessed my coworkers get thrown under the bus by negligent and incompetent management to cover their own rears or by climbers stomping on their peers' faces to try to get a leg up. I wasn't ever the target of any of this because I wasn't seeking advancement and only intended to stick around through school, but I was sufficiently benign that most people eventually loosened their lips around me and I realized just how toxic the whole place was and how that toxicity was structurally reinforced and incentivized from the top down.

Any time workers tried to make complaints about this type of behavior, the response was always about how that kind of thing goes against Starbucks' values and culture, but when observing management (including district and corporate level), it's clear that Starbucks is a two-faced organization that absolutely does incentivize and reward that kind of behavior while claiming not to behind the veil of plausible deniability, but I saw enough to be certain.

Pay and benefits were mediocre-to-bad. Management all the way up to the corporate level was sociopathically dishonest and exploitative, stepping on people without hesitation or remorse while disingenuously hiding behind reams of nice sounding PR talk to paper over their callous disregard. Pretty much felt like the company was run by Lannisters.

pros: Had a very thorough training period with lots of useful info. Was great getting to work with my fellow baristas and had some great managers that I was able to work through problems with. Got to expand my multitasking skills and was given many perks like discounts and even free leftover food!
cons:
The messages from corporate were awful. We had shortages of supplies and food constantly, and there were so many time-consuming tasks for floor managers that could've been streamlined so they'd have more time to help customers. 
Also there are the 'third place discussion' series meant to encourage comradery but came off as fake and disingenuous. They were also used for PR reactions after public scandals (think of the black men loitering in a starbucks who were asked to leave or a barista writing 'pig' on a cop's cup). After these we were all given a lesson on how to avoid these situations again. Because of how reactionary they were, they ended up contradicting each other. We were basically being disciplined for things we weren't responsible for. 
Ultimately these were just time wasters and pulled us away from serving customers.
Also as a personal note, as an autistic person I was not given enough accommodation to make my job as easy as the regular person's. They need to work on their accessibility issues.

review_title: Terrible culture of bullying and intimidation
pros: Free coffee, free food. Building positive relationships with customers
cons:
Only focus is on customers. Management and company as a whole does not care about creating a safe work environment for its staff. They create toxic environments and when reported to HR nothing is taken seriously. 
I was being harassed and bullied on a daily basis to the point of having panic attacks. I was also being harassed and disrespected by a few customers and one even assaulted me. I reported these to my manager and HR on many occassions nothing was done. In fact I was told to ignore it or that if I couldn’t find anyone to validate my claims there was nothing that could be done.

Starbucks claim they do “a lot” for partners but when it’s crunch time they don’t follow through. As long as the customer is happy it doesn’t matter about the partner, they can be bullied, disrespected, and more and it does not matter. The mission and values they claim to live by in the employee handbook is a complete lie!

review_title: Has rapidly gone downhill over the last 5 years.
pros: - Teaches new skills and how to work efficiently with a team in a fast paced environment.
cons:
- At one time, had some of the best pay and benefits in the part time F&B industry. Now, both are below industry standard, many perks and benefits are being scaled down or eliminated completely, and some stores in higher-COL areas only earning around as much as $10/hr. 

- Starbucks hires many of their upper management externally, which leads to impossible demands and goals placed on customer facing partners because DM's have no idea what actually goes on in a store.

- If you get stuck with a bad SM and/or shift supervisors, your time, resources, and physical and mental well-being WILL be exploited for every penny they can get from you.

review_title: Not sure if it is worth it right now
pros:
Great benefits package! 
From the free Spotify Premium, to education and healthcare assistance, to coffee markouts. 
One free food and unlimited drinks during our scheduled work day is definitely one of my favorite perks. 

A good crew makes for a really fun work environment and can be really motivating to make the day go smoother. 

There are a lot of opportunities to learn about coffee and be involved in “coffee culture”. The Coffee Master program is a great challenge to take on if you are interested in learning the history of coffee and how to pair them.

Not all customers are as terrible as it would seem. Making valuable connections with customers and getting to know each other is a really rewarding experience.
cons:
Unreasonable expectations from corporate which trickles down from the District Manager all the way down to baristas. Everything has to be the best it can be. They want us to always go above and beyond while having the best KPI’s but somehow make that all happen with limited staffing due to labor cuts; meanwhile, sales and customers have increased exponentially and we are drowning in a sea of work that we just cannot handle. 

You can forget about being able to take sick/personal time without being guilt tripped, especially as a supervisor. The expectation that we can make it to every single shift that is allotted to us, without an emergency or illness is highly unreasonable. No work-life balance if you want to be full-time, as this is a shift based job. 

Tremendous labor cuts have lead to full-time workers receiving part-time hours. How are we supposed to make ends meet when we are barely given any hours?

Incredibly high-paced and demanding job (both physically and mentally/emotionally). Some people will make or break your day depending on whether or not they throw a fit about their customer experience. If we do things right, we aren’t acknowledged as this is an expectation, but do things wrong for the customer and all hell breaks loose.

review_title: Great coworkers, poor pay and interactions
pros: Starbucks had great benefits. They had insurance, education, etc. They also are very flexible with their schedule. I mostly liked the coworkers and team you work with. Got to know most of them, and still friends with some to this day.
cons: The pay was not good. They didn’t accept credit card tips. It was mostly cash tips which weren’t as common. And the pay at the time was below average. I couldn’t understand why we didn’t accept credit card tips because it would improve our pay without coming out of Starbucks paycheck. And we also received a lot of requests that we should do credit card tipping. Not only was pay pretty bad, but customers have it out for Starbucks workers. I don’t know what it is with them but there’s been several times when customers have thrown drinks at us or even insulted us for no reason.

review_title: Excellent Values, poor work life balance
pros: Starbucks is truly a value driven company, a rarity for such a large corporation. Their values were reflected across the company, and made life as a retail/foodbev manager more bearable, as you felt you were making more of an impact every day with your work. Benefits (especially the perks) are expansive and improved year over year. Being such a large corporation there were copious amount of resources and standards available across the company at all levels.
cons: Terrible, terrible work life balance at the store level. Boundaries were exceptionally difficult to put in place as leadership role and not supported by upper management (District Manager and above) due to role expectations and work load. Due to long hours many SMs actually make less than those they manage. Exceptionally difficult to transition out of store level management into corporate roles, so much so that many remarkable leaders left the company unfortunately.

review_title: Dead shots, dead souls, and dead ends
pros:
Learn customer service skills (including how to deal with difficult people)
Structured and methodical system - transfers well to other service jobs
Free drinks (you can only drink so much though)
Health and dental benefits (can only apply a few times a year I think)
Some locations have good people or team environments (these are rare though)
The few remaining cafe stores, though similarly busy, are funner to work at than drive-thru locations (less multi-tasking and more personal) - at least in my experience
cons:
Very draining - emotionally, energetically, physically too
A true rat race - struggle to get full-time work hours
Lots of gatekeeping and limited upward mobility
Very cliquey people and teams
Poor and indirect communication - an unfortunate and I would say painful culture of politeness and political correctness
The coffee is truly vile - best described as "hot garbage water"

review_title: Great benefits and pay but the mental health isn’t worth the sacrifice.
pros: The benefits are great and the fact that they offer them for all partners is amazing. The “concept” of the company is great but please look at cons on the methods to get there.
cons: A lot of those who have been at the company for long like the company itself i feel like has lost its way on their mission statement. They quote policy and goals and inspiring speeches but when it comes to practice it feels like they drop the ball. Investing in your partners isn’t something you can do half way. Being a manager there is such a pressure on labor but still developing and coaching. We want to give people the benefit as well as always expecting the good but I’ve been told to document people to see if that wake them up. The way my direct manager speaks to me isn’t correct but as long as the right verbiage and not the right approach is done then it’s not seen as negative. And this is a person with many years in this company. The retaliation that we see in peoples stories is felt and at this point asking us to hire for this culture without the investment and being upset when people have to have more than 1 job and can’t give us their entire lives is ridiculous and unprofessional.

pros: The benefits at Starbucks are amazing. They are super affordable and GOOD when it comes to coverage. They offer so many options to tailor to a person's specific needs.
cons:
It is SO hard to promote. The pay is very hush-hush when asking superiors what the promotion pay would be. When you do want to promote it can take forever and often the manager has the ability to stall this process. The pay is also not great with no rewards for learning new skills. You are expected to learn all of the skills at once with no tiered pay scale for advancing. The shift supervisor salary (if someone is willing to tell you) is not great, maybe $2-$4 more than a barista, but they are expected to be available for 30+ hours a week (makes getting a second job to compensate for lack of pay very difficult) and the only people who can cover your shift if you are sick are other shift supervisors. Often there are only 4 at a store (depending on the size of the store) and 1-2 of those are already working the same day that you may need coverage. I have worked with shifts more than a couple of times who come to work super sick because no one can cover and they literally have the keys to the store so they have to come in.
Promoting to store manager is ridiculously difficult and they do mostly outside hiring rather than internal promoting. The turnover is so high because it's too hard to move up.

Overall, great as a filler job or if you just need the benefits, but if you are looking for a long-term career, try In-N-Out.

4. Has an interesting and diverse community of coworkers.

3. Mainly hires and keeps people in there teens, and young adulthood, meaning that mature conversation can sometimes be fleeting at best.

review_title: Working part time while studying full time
job_title: Part Time Barista in Subang Jaya
pros: Main reason why I work here is because of the flexible shifts. Since I was a full time student, I can work a full month during semester breaks and only work on weekends when a new semester starts. Also allowed to take study breaks whenever I need to prepare for finals.
cons:
It can be exhausting when there are a lot of customers and you only have 2-3 people including the shift manager in a shift. You might get a break way later because sometimes you need to wait for another partner to clock in to cover your position. But, this may vary for each store.

Other than that, I do think the people working around you play a huge part in creating either a good or bad environment for you. I honestly love working here but due to some people, I decided to leave my job earlier before I look for other jobs. Just pray that you will be surrounded by good people.

review_title: Good for some bad for most
pros:
The benefits are really good
Free spotify
Free food
Free drinks
Tips
cons:
You will be asked to adapt to working with:
Broken espresso machines 
Broken fridges
Broken ovens
Broken registers 
Broken sticker printers
Being constantly understaffed.
My store is a busy drive thru in an expensive neighborhood, so you can imagine the Karen's when our store is broken.
If your store is a drive thru you will be expected to keep up with cafe, drive thru, and mobile orders. There is no cap on how many mobile orders you can receive so you need to keep up regardless, while having adults who act like toddlers stare you down. Also there's a shortage of basically everything. We have run out of:
Hot cups
Hot lids
Cold lids
Vanilla
Other syrups
Main ingredients in new drinks
Milk
Coffee beans
Food 
Whip cream.
I've had to work to partners who have assaulted other partners.
Where I work supervisors get paid $20 an hour to not do anything. And the only person at the store guaranteed a full 40 hours is the manager. So have fun trying to pay your bills, in full, on time.

pros: I’ve worked at two different Starbucks locations so far and my experiences were wildly different. At my first location my manager was wonderful. She hired enough staff so we weren’t too overworked. She responded promptly to any concerns we brought to her. If your store is well staffed with kind coworkers then you’ll probably have a great time. Work in that case isn’t too stressful and pay is decent with fairly good benefits.
cons: At my second location, the managers of sister stores were basically playing hot potato with managing our store and it was a train wreck. None of our concerns were taken seriously. I was harassed by a customer at one point, told my manager, and she said she would do something about it, but he continued to visit the store regularly with no repercussions. We had no leadership and food safety rules were regularly violated and no-one cared. Pay is decent but not amazing. We don’t have a way to receive electronic tips, so tips are limited to cash only which means we don’t get very much.

review_title: Solid flexible job -  but it's still food retail

Coworkers are fun, the work is fast paced and usually keeps me engaged. There are a lot of benefits and perks - so you'll find something you enjoy using in the perk package. Training and advancement options are there, and they are internal - which is better than some other major retailers I have worked for.
cons: Dress code is still a little archaic. You're still working with the public and getting paid non-living wages (for most of us anyway. It is possible to make a living wage with this company.) The job gets repetitive after awhile. While the schedule is relatively flexible, sometimes it's hard to keep a work/life balance and get enough hours in.

pros:
My SM was the greatest boss I’ve ever had. She works to accommodate everyone and ever changing school schedules, treats her employees with equity, and defends her workers against aggressive and verbally abusive customers. 

Coworkers are my second family.
cons:
Exhausting/entitled/demanding customers. I worked for Starbucks for almost 10 years and this is across the board at different locations. Sometimes customers behave in socially unacceptable ways to get free drinks and food items or “just because”, as Starbucks culture allows customers to treat the employees so very poorly due to high prices (I assume). My last manager defended us and allowed us to terminate interactions with overtly rude and nasty individuals. 

My Starbucks is extremely high volume, and was very stressful due to call-outs, shortage of staff and endless tickets for drinks due ro mobile orders, Uber orders, cafe and drive-thru orders. We had a high turn overate.

In my final opinion it’s a great job if you like high volume, early work hours (4am the earliest), fun coworkers, and desire good benefits for part time work (20 hours at least/week). If you are easily stressed by customer altercations, 30+ drink tickets at once, and being often short staffed - this is not the job for you. I also personally feel that the $1 over minimum wage that the company touts is not nearly enough for the pace/workload and baristas are being worked to exhaustion. (This is not exclusive to baristas, my SM was constantly being pushed and stretched to cover other stores and to get her employees to work faster for better drive thru times, more sales, and to keep an impossible standard of “making customer connections” while pushing faster window times.

pros: I worked part-time here as a second job. I knew what I was getting into when I took the job. It is not glamorous, but the company offers great benefits and does try to take care of its employees, significantly more than most other companies do, especially within their industry. I met many great people, worked here for almost six years, and wouldn't change that experience.
cons: It is a fast-paced and physically demanding job. People think they will make cool coffee creations and be artistic in a laid back atmosphere, but at this point, there is a lot less skill and creativity involved and more just learning the system and repetition. This is essentially fast food work. You will spend a lot of time doing dishes, sweeping and mopping floors, cleaning bathrooms (depending on the time of day you work).

review_title: Work never ends in salaried positions
pros: When I started in 2015, this company was amazing and stood out from a lot of service industry jobs. The benefits are good, especially for part-time people. Health, dental, and vision had great coverage at a lot of places. Loved the push to prioritize mental health by partnering with Lyra and offering free membership to Headspace. The free Spotify premium was my favorite benefit honestly! I will say the core mission and values of Starbucks were lived up to a lot of the time and if executive leadership noticed a miss, they were usually quick to address it and take action.
cons: After reaching salaried status, work never ended, especially after the pandemic hit. There was always something coming up outside of your time in the store. Between someone calling out, testing positive, the insane turnover, and adding the basic responsibilities, it felt like you were multitasking into a mental breakdown. Work-life balance tanked the minute store managers were all issued MacBooks, it was great for flexibility, but that's a double-edged sword. Compensation was lacking greatly for salaried positions and around the time I left, I'm glad to say it was being addressed.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Big Bear Lake, CA
pros: Great benefits that I love
cons: Not enough pay for me

pros:
- Nurturing and hiring staffs
- Customer connection
cons:
- Terrible coffee and coffee culture. Once you actually learn a thing or two about coffee, you will realize how bad it is.

- Coffee tremendously depends on multiple factors.

- Beans and it's characteristics.
- What's your TDS?
- How good is your pulled shot?
- Grind input weight vs output weight
- How hard you've tamp'ed your coffee
- Shots vs milk / breve ratio
- Milk temperature is different per drink. Because drinks are size dependent.

I am oversimplying it, but it's a very nuanced. Very much like cooking.

- Terrible "grinder". It's all-in-one machine. Grinder+ espresso machine/steamer. Once you've used some decent equipments such as Van Der (espresso machine) or Mazzer (grinder), you will realize how laughable it is.
